Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Bes brandishing a sword and shield. Mould-made and hollow with vent in back. Crudely made. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with purple core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Naked Bes with round shield and sword are dated from the late Ptolemaic (Török 1995, no.17, late 2nd to 1st century BC; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, Pl.77.1-4, no. 426-33, 2nd BC to 3rd century AD) and Roman period (Dunand 1990, no.39). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.210) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 95, no. 286)
